{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3501224,"name":"ahuang","username":"ahuang","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/13edae/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-03T23:57:45.089Z","cooked":"

Whenever we try to deploy to the robot, we get a fatal python error: Aborted and a frozen runpy in _run_code and _run_module_as_main.
We have looked over our code multiple times without seeing anything that would cause these errors. We also tried reimaging the roborio with no luck.
We are using the most recent 2025 version of robotpy
Everything from the deploy terminal is copied down below (A few lines are deleted for autonomy) . Any help would be appreciated!

roboRIO 1 or 2? Does it occur if you run a project that doesn’t use PathPlanner?

It looks like you are using Python 3.13, but that isn’t a supported version of Python for robotpy.

Python Installation Guide — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

The documentation is out of date.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-02-04T03:03:55.316Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":41,"readers_count":40,"score":38.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":485006,"topic_slug":"frozen-runpy-and-fatal-python-error","display_username":"Dustin Spicuzza","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":62967,"username":"jennyfrc","name":null,"avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/cc9497/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":11063,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"RobotPy Guy, WPILib Developer"},"post_url":"/t/frozen-runpy-and-fatal-python-error/485006/4","custom_user_title":"RobotPy Guy, WPILib Developer","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3501434,"name":null,"username":"jennyfrc","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/cc9497/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-04T04:36:20.764Z","cooked":"

I didn’t realize that 3.13 was supported now. That’s good to know.

As for the original question, I would do an update of robotpy since I have 2025.2.1.1 of both robotpy and WPILib. I’m not sure if that would cause this, but I have seen some quirky version issues this season and would start there. I would also do a pip list to make sure that any 3rd party libraries you reference (Rev, Pathplanner, Photonvision, etc.) are all updated too. Finally, make sure to sync your code if any of these libraries do update.

However, the fact that a fatal Python error is also shown makes me wonder if there is something going on with your code. I believe that I have mostly seen that when there is a code issue.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-02-04T04:36:20.764Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":37,"readers_count":36,"score":62.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":485006,"topic_slug":"frozen-runpy-and-fatal-python-error","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/python-swerve-issues-and-help/493057/2","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Python Swerve Issues and Help","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":11063,"username":"virtuald","name":"Dustin Spicuzza","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/virtuald/{size}/65268_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62967,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/frozen-runpy-and-fatal-python-error/485006/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3501438,"name":"Dustin Spicuzza","username":"virtuald","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/virtuald/{size}/65268_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-04T04:39:14.267Z","cooked":"
jennyfrc:

However, the fact that a fatal Python error is also shown makes me wonder if there is something going on with your code. I believe that I have mostly seen that when there is a code issue.

Historically this has been true, but this year (and for this user in other CD posts) it seems to occur when the RoboRIO runs out of memory.

I’ve created a github issue to track this at Memory issues · Issue #149 · robotpy/mostrobotpy · GitHub. The core problem is that pathplannerlib uses numpy, and numpy takes up a TON of memory relative to the RoboRIO (around 40MB). Of that, OpenBLAS (which is used for accelerating some numpy operations) uses maybe 26MB. I’m going to make a numpy build that doesn’t use OpenBLAS that you can try out, but it might take a bit.

But really, if you’re going to use python + pathplannerlib, it seems that this year you really should be using a RoboRIO 2.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-02-04T04:39:14.267Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":37,"readers_count":36,"score":22.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":485006,"topic_slug":"frozen-runpy-and-fatal-python-error","display_username":"Dustin Spicuzza","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/robotpy/mostrobotpy/issues/149","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Memory issues · Issue #149 · robotpy/mostrobotpy · GitHub","clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":11063,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"RobotPy Guy, WPILib Developer"},"post_url":"/t/frozen-runpy-and-fatal-python-error/485006/6","custom_user_title":"RobotPy Guy, WPILib Developer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3501485,"name":"Dustin Spicuzza","username":"virtuald","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/virtuald/{size}/65268_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-04T06:05:35.741Z","cooked":"

I built a version of numpy that doesn’t use OpenBLAS. For now, you need to explicitly enable it in your pyproject.toml:

[tool.robotpy]

requires = [
    "numpy==2.2.1.dev0; platform_machine == 'roborio'",
]

Run robotpy sync and on the next deploy it should install that specific version of numpy to your robot.

With this version of numpy, it seems to save around 15MB of RAM.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-02-04T06:05:35.741Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":34,"readers_count":33,"score":21.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":485006,"topic_slug":"frozen-runpy-and-fatal-python-error","display_username":"Dustin Spicuzza","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":11063,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"RobotPy Guy, WPILib Developer"},"post_url":"/t/frozen-runpy-and-fatal-python-error/485006/7","custom_user_title":"RobotPy Guy, WPILib Developer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3502111,"name":"ahuang","username":"ahuang","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/13edae/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-04T20:19:17.744Z","cooked":"

No, this error does not occur in a project that does use Pathplanner. We are using roboRIO 1

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-02-04T20:19:17.744Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":29,"readers_count":28,"score":5.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":485006,"topic_slug":"frozen-runpy-and-fatal-python-error","display_username":"ahuang","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":65,"username":"Joe_Ross","name":"Joe Ross","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joe_ross/{size}/37_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66158,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/frozen-runpy-and-fatal-python-error/485006/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3502142,"name":"ahuang","username":"ahuang","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/13edae/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-04T20:39:45.170Z","cooked":"

When we try to run robotpy sync, we get this error:
ERROR: Cannot install numpy==2.2.1.dev0 and robotpy[all]==2025.2.1.1 because these package versions have conflicting dependencies.

The conflict is caused by:
The user requested numpy==2.2.1.dev0
robotpy[all] 2025.2.1.1 depends on numpy==2.1.3; platform_machine == “roborio” and extra == “all”

To fix this you could try to:

  1. loosen the range of package versions you’ve specified
  2. remove package versions to allow pip to attempt to solve the dependency conflict

ERROR: ResolutionImpossible: for help visit Dependency Resolution - pip documentation v25.1.dev0
ERROR: pip download failed

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-02-04T20:41:43.403Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":31,"readers_count":30,"score":21.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":485006,"topic_slug":"frozen-runpy-and-fatal-python-error","display_username":"ahuang","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://pip.pypa.io/en/latest/topics/dependency-resolution/#dealing-with-dependency-conflicts","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Dependency Resolution - pip documentation v25.1.dev0","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":11063,"username":"virtuald","name":"Dustin Spicuzza","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/virtuald/{size}/65268_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66158,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/frozen-runpy-and-fatal-python-error/485006/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3502151,"name":"Dustin Spicuzza","username":"virtuald","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/virtuald/{size}/65268_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-04T20:46:56.896Z","cooked":"

No, that would not fix it.

Remove ‘all’ from your robotpy_extras in pyproject.toml and only include the things that you need, and that should fix it. The list of allowable fields is at 3rd Party Libraries — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

Even better, don’t use robotpy_extras at all, and only use requires to include pypi packages. We will be getting rid of robotpy_extras next year.

Or, upgrade to 2025.2.1.2, which I just pushed (might take a few minutes to make it to pypi), and it should allow the robotpy_extras = ["all"] and the requires line that I published above.

We upgraded to 2025.2.1.2 and we used the [“all”] got
“”, line 198, in _run_module_as_main
File “”, line 88, in _run_code

When we removed "all’ from the robotpy_extras in the .toml file, and only included the things we needed, we got: user requested robotpy==2025.2.1.0 and user requested robotpy==2025.2.1.2, even though we pip installed 2025.2.1.1 and changed all of the robotpy versions in the toml file to 2025.2.1.1. When we try to run sync, the version in the toml file changes from 2025.2.1.1 back to 2025.2.1.2
We tried to pip install the 2025.2.1.1 version on robotpy, but it gave us an error about conflicting dependancies.

I don’t know what your pyproject.toml contains because you didn’t post it, but I was guessing that you were using all. If you aren’t, then don’t use all, use whatever you were using before but just upgrade the version.

This works fine for me:

#
# Use this configuration file to control what RobotPy packages are installed
# on your RoboRIO
#

[tool.robotpy]

# Version of robotpy this project depends on
robotpy_version = "2025.2.1.2"

# Which extra RobotPy components should be installed
# -> equivalent to `pip install robotpy[extra1, ...]
robotpy_extras = [
    "all",
]

# Other pip packages to install
requires = [
    "numpy==2.2.1.dev0; platform_machine == 'roborio'",
]

This is our pyproject.toml file:
It’s the same exact file that you have and we are getting the same error

#
# Use this configuration file to control what RobotPy packages are installed
# on your RoboRIO
#
[tool.robotpy]
# Version of robotpy this project depends on
robotpy_version = "2025.2.1.2"
# Which extra RobotPy components should be installed
# -> equivalent to `pip install robotpy[extra1, ...]
robotpy_extras = [
    "all",
]
# Other pip packages to install
requires = [
    "numpy==2.2.1.dev0; platform_machine == 'roborio'",
]
